name: Grimpen Mire
description: A dangerous peat bog on Dartmoor, infamous for its quicksand and treacherous conditions, playing a key role in the novel’s mystery.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Grimpen Mire is a notorious peat bog located on Dartmoor, characterized by its soft, waterlogged ground that poses a deadly hazard to unwary travelers. Known for quicksand and deceptive patches of stable land, it is frequently enveloped in mist, enhancing its reputation as a foreboding and perilous landmark. The mire is integral to the novel’s suspense, acting both as a physical danger and a symbol of the unknown.

content.title: Appearance
content.body: The Mire appears as a seemingly flat expanse of boggy ground covered in water, mosses, and tall grasses, often surrounded by low-growing shrubbery and heather. It is shrouded in fog on many days, giving it an almost otherworldly presence. The ground is deceptively soft and unstable, making any crossing a potential death trap, as the edges can give way beneath a person’s weight.

content.title: History
content.body: Grimpen Mire’s history is steeped in local rumor and legend as a place where past travelers have perished after being swallowed by the bog. It has existed for centuries as a natural hazard on Dartmoor. In the context of the Baskerville estate and story, it serves as a critical geographic element, expected to have claimed an unfortunate victim related to the Baskerville curse.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: Within "The Hound of the Baskervilles," Grimpen Mire is the site of a major plot event—an attempted murder disguised by the treacherous landscape. The mire’s lethal terrain compounds the danger posed by the sinister hound and is utilized both to symbolize the enigmatic threat and to physically isolate characters. It emphasizes the brutality and isolation of the moor.
